PPSGCN: A Privacy-Preserving Subgraph Sampling Based Distributed GCN Training Method

Binchi Zhang zbc0725@stu.xjtu.edu.cn Xi’an Jiaotong UniversityNo.28, West Xianning RoadXi’anShaanxiChina ,  Minnan Luo minnluo@xjtu.edu.cn Xi’an Jiaotong UniversityNo.28, West Xianning RoadXi’anShaanxiChina ,  Shangbin Feng wind˙binteng@stu.xjtu.edu.cn Xi’an Jiaotong UniversityNo.28, West Xianning RoadXi’anShaanxiChina ,  Ziqi Liu ziqiliu@antfin.com Ant GroupChina ,  Jun Zhou jun.zhoujun@antfin.com Ant GroupChina  and  Qinghua Zheng qhzheng@mail.xjtu.edu.cn Xi’an Jiaotong UniversityNo.28, West Xianning RoadXi’anShaanxiChina
Abstract.

Graph convolutional networks (GCNs) have been widely adopted for graph representation learning and achieved impressive performance. For larger graphs stored separately on different clients, distributed GCN training algorithms were proposed to improve efficiency and scalability. However, existing methods directly exchange node features between different clients, which results in data privacy leakage. Federated learning was incorporated in graph learning to tackle data privacy, while they suffer from severe performance drop due to non-iid data distribution. Besides, these approaches generally involve heavy communication and memory overhead during the training process. In light of these problems, we propose a Privacy-Preserving Subgraph sampling based distributed GCN training method (PPSGCN), which preserves data privacy and significantly cuts back on communication and memory overhead. Specifically, PPSGCN employs a star-topology client-server system. We firstly sample a local node subset in each client to form a global subgraph, which greatly reduces communication and memory costs. We then conduct local computation on each client with features or gradients of the sampled nodes. Finally, all clients securely communicate with the central server with homomorphic encryption to combine local results while preserving data privacy. Compared with federated graph learning methods, our PPSGCN model is trained on a global graph to avoid the negative impact of local data distribution. We prove that our PPSGCN algorithm would converge to a local optimum with probability 1. Experiment results on three prevalent benchmarks demonstrate that our algorithm significantly reduces communication and memory overhead while maintaining desirable performance. Further studies not only demonstrate the fast convergence of PPSGCN, but discuss the trade-off between communication and local computation cost as well.

1. Introduction

Graphs and network data have been increasingly leveraged in real-world applications such as social network analysis (Hamilton et al., 2017b; Feng et al., 2021), protein structure (Fout, 2017) and recommender systems (He et al., 2020; Eksombatchai et al., 2018; Ying et al., 2018). Among them, graph convolutional networks (GCNs) are widely adopted to learn representations of nodes and graphs. For large-scale graphs such as PinSage (Ying et al., 2018) and Aligraph (Zhu et al., 2019) which involve billions of nodes and edges, GCN models could not be sufficiently trained on a single machine due to memory limitations. Besides, large graphs in real-world applications are often partitioned into different subgraphs which are stored in distributed memory architectures. These problems call for distributed GCN training algorithms that address memory issues and improve GCN scalability.

Existing distributed GCN algorithms generally run in parallel to update a global model with data in all devices. Tripathy et al. (2020) proposes CAGNET, a family of parallel GCN training frameworks. CAGNET divides clients into small groups to restrict the broadcast domain. Each group calculates a part of result, which results in lower communication cost. Jiang and Rumi (2021) presents a skewed node sampling strategy which samples more local neighbors than remote ones for each node. Similarly, BDS-GCN (Wan et al., 2020) uniformly samples training subgraphs from the boundary node set. Both sampling-based methods largely reduce the communication overhead. In addition, BDS-GCN exhibits better robustness across different settings of device number due to sampling uniformity.

Although existing distributed GCN training methods were generally successful, they fail to address the challenges of privacy and overhead in the distributed setting. The challenge of privacy requires distributed GCN algorithms to preserve data privacy between clients where different subgraphs are scattered in physically distributed client networks. Existing methods directly exchange raw node features or gradient information between different clients, which induces high risks of privacy leakage. Federated learning is adopted to address this issue (Wu et al., 2021; Wang et al., 2020; He et al., 2021; Mei et al., 2019), whereas these methods severely suffer from a performance drop under non-iid local data distribution. In federated graph learning methods, gradients of local weights are only associated with local nodes. Therefore when data distributions on different clients are uneven, it’s difficult for the global model to converge to the global optimum. Besides, the challenge of overhead requires distributed GCN algorithms to significantly reduce communication and memory overhead to improve efficiency and scalability (Tripathy et al., 2020; Angerd et al., 2020). Existing approaches attempted to reduce communication cost with graph sampling (Jiang and Rumi, 2021; Wan et al., 2020) or partition (Tripathy et al., 2020), while they fail to strike a balance between communication and memory overhead and maintain desirable performance.

In light of these issues, we propose a Privacy-Preserving Subgraph sampling based distributed GCN training method (PPSGCN), a novel and scalable distributed GCN training algorithm to address privacy concerns and reduce training overhead. Specifically, we develop a matrix-form distributed forward and backward propagation method with encryption technique in a star-topology client-server system. The training algorithm in each layer could be formulated in three steps. Firstly we sample a local node subset in each client to form a global subgraph for training. Each client then calculates local terms with features and gradients of sampled nodes in GCN steps. Finally, central server aggregates local terms from all clients with homomorphic encryption and sends summations back to clients. In this way, our model hides local structural information and node features from different clients and reliably preserves data privacy during transmission. Moreover, we update model parameters globally with nodes from different clients, which improves the performance compared to federated graph learning methods in non-iid local data distribution. We further prove the unbiasedness of our sampling approach and the convergence of the PPSGCN algorithm in theory. Our main contributions are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We propose PPSGCN, a novel distributed GCN training method to learn graph representations in the distributed setting, which preserves data privacy and significantly improves training efficiency. Sufficient theoretical analyses are held on convergence and low training overhead of PPSGCN.

  • •

    We propose a novel subgraph sampling approach, which samples local node subsets in all clients to form a global training subgraph. It is an unbiased sampling technique and greatly improves GNN scalability in distributed settings.

  • •

    Extensive experiments on three benchmarks demonstrate that PPSGCN significantly reduces communication and memory overhead while maintaining desirable performance.

2. Related Work

Distributed Training of GCN

As graph datasets grow in size, graph neural networks could not be sufficiently trained on a single machine due to memory limitations. Therefore, many researchers proposed to train GCN models in distributed settings. The primary challenge of distributed GCN training methods is their high communication overhead, and many solutions are presented to reduce communication costs. Tripathy et al. (2020) present a family of parallel GCN training frameworks (CAGNET). They reduce communication by partitioning adjacency matrices (sparse) and feature matrices (dense) in different ways and distributing calculation of their products to different clients. Among all variants, CAGNET (1.5d) leads to minimum communication cost and decreases it by a constant factor of C𝐶C while storing redundant node features, which leads to C𝐶C times more memory overhead. Wan et al. (2020) develop graph sampling methods on boundary nodes which are responsible for communication, and boost the throughput by up to 500%. However, their solution stores node features in the boundary sets multiple times and lead to increased memory overhead. Jiang and Rumi (2021) propose a skewed node sampling method which samples local node in larger probability to reduce the communication. However, their method encounters a serious performance deterioration when the number of clients increases. In light of these methods’ problems, we work to propose a distributed GCN training algorithm that strikes a balance between communication and memory overhead, while being robust to different settings of client numbers.

Federated Graph Learning

With growing concerns of privacy in machine learning, federated learning methods (McMahan et al., 2017; Smith et al., 2017; Li et al., 2018) were proposed to train models on data-storing devices. In the federated learning setting, it’s prohibited to directly transfer raw data among distributed clients. To address privacy concerns in graph-based problems, researchers incorporate federated learning in graph neural networks. Zheng et al. (2021) present a federated graph learning model which exploits Bayesian optimization and JS divergence to improve performance. It protects data privacy by secret sharing transmission. Mei et al. (2019) propose a similarity-based federated graph learning framework to better leverage distant neighbors with a distance function. Zhou et al. (2020) present a federated graph learning framework in vertically partitioned dataset. They calculate the first few layers locally and aggregate local results in the central server to calculate the remaining layers. They only transmit hidden node embeddings after local training, which largely reduces communication cost while preserving data privacy. However, these methods suffer from performance drop on data with non-iid distributions (He et al., 2021), which is common in real-world scenarios.

Sampling on Graph

GCN models are often trained with gradient descent methods and mini-batching. For large graphs and graphs with high average degrees, one minibatch of nodes might over expand to the whole graph as the network goes deeper, which is known as ”neighbor explosion”. This problem seriously reduces the scalability of vanilla GCN training algorithms. Therefore, researchers resort to sampling methods to address this issue, including node sampling (Hamilton et al., 2017a; Chen et al., 2017), layer sampling (Chen et al., 2018; Zou et al., 2019) and graph sampling (Chiang et al., 2019; Zeng et al., 2019). For node sampling methods, Hamilton et al. (2017a) randomly sample a fixed number of neighbors for each node in a subset and add sampled nodes to the subset in each layer. This method effectively reduces the size of minibatch, while one node might be sampled repeatedly in one layer. For layer sampling methods, Chen et al. (2018) randomly sample a fixed number of nodes for minibatch in each layer. It solves the repetitive sampling problem, while one node might be repeatedly calculated in different minibatches, leading to lower training efficiency. For subgraph sampling methods, Zeng et al. (2019) propose several sampling approaches which directly sample the training graph for all layers. With the help of sampling, GCN models achieves better efficiency and state-of-the-art performance on larger graph datasets in centralized settings. In this paper, we explore ways to incorporate graph sampling for distributed GCN training to improve efficiency and scalability.

3.1. Model Backbone

The architecture of PPSGCN is shown in Figure 1. Our distributed framework is based on a star-topology client-server system in federated learning setting, where a reliable central server is leveraged to securely aggregate information from different clients.

It’s evident that we could calculate Equation 6 in the same way as Equation 3 because of their identical forms. Then the gradient of loss function ℒℒ\mathcal{L} with respect to the lt​hsuperscript𝑙𝑡ℎl^{th} layer weight matrix can be derived as

(7) ∇𝑾lℒ=∑j=1m(𝒁jl−1)T​∇𝒁jl−1ℒsubscript∇superscript𝑾𝑙ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒁𝑙1𝑗𝑇subscript∇subscriptsuperscript𝒁𝑙1𝑗ℒ\nabla_{{\boldsymbol{W}}^{l}}\mathcal{L}=\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left({\boldsymbol{Z}}^{l-1}_{j}\right)^{T}\nabla_{{\boldsymbol{Z}}^{l-1}_{j}}\mathcal{L}

for l=1,⋯,L𝑙1⋯𝐿l=1,\cdots,L, where each term of summation could be calculated locally within the corresponding client.

In the training process, we should conduct communication between clients and central server to compute these equations in forward and backward propagation. Intuitively, the communication overhead in our training process is considerable when training on a large graph. Furthermore, we require large memory overhead to store hidden representation matrices 𝒁ilsubscriptsuperscript𝒁𝑙𝑖{\boldsymbol{Z}}^{l}_{i} for l=1,⋯,L𝑙1⋯𝐿l=1,\cdots,L in the computation graph. Details of training overhead are analyzed in Section 4.2. To improve the training efficiency, we resort to a subgraph sampling method in distributed setting introduced subsequently.

3.2. Sampling Technique

Consequently, our objective function ℒ​(𝓦)ℒ𝓦\mathcal{L\left({\boldsymbol{W}}\right)} could be reformulated as ℒS​(𝑾)=∑i=1mpi​L​o​s​sSi​(𝒁SiL,𝑾)subscriptℒ𝑆𝑾superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑝𝑖𝐿𝑜𝑠subscript𝑠subscript𝑆𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒁subscript𝑆𝑖𝐿𝑾\mathcal{L}_{S}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{m}p_{i}Loss_{S_{i}}\left({\boldsymbol{Z}}_{S_{i}}^{L},{\boldsymbol{W}}\right).

For communication in the training process, we adopt Paillier encryption technique (Paillier, 1999) to preserve local data privacy. The encrypted communication steps in Algorithm 1 could be formulated as follows,

  1. (1)

    Clients and central server request key pairs (p​k,s​k)𝑝𝑘𝑠𝑘(pk,sk).

  2. (2)

    Each client Cjsubscript𝐶𝑗C_{j} encrypts local terms {𝑿i​j}i=1,⋯,msubscriptsubscript𝑿𝑖𝑗𝑖1⋯𝑚\{{\boldsymbol{X}}_{ij}\}_{i=1,\cdots,m} with public key as Enc​(𝑿i​j,p​k)Encsubscript𝑿𝑖𝑗𝑝𝑘\emph{Enc}\left({\boldsymbol{X}}_{ij},pk\right), then sends to the central server.

  3. (3)

    Central server sums up the ciphertext of local terms S​U​Mi=Enc​(∑j=1m𝑿i​j,p​k)𝑆𝑈subscript𝑀𝑖Encsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑿𝑖𝑗𝑝𝑘SUM_{i}=\emph{Enc}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{m}{\boldsymbol{X}}_{ij},pk\right) and sends S​U​Mi𝑆𝑈subscript𝑀𝑖SUM_{i} to client Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i} for i=1,⋯,m𝑖1⋯𝑚i=1,\cdots,m.

  4. (4)

    Each client Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i} receives S​U​Mi𝑆𝑈subscript𝑀𝑖SUM_{i} and decrypts it with secret key as ∑j=1m𝑿i​j=Dec​(S​U​Mi,s​ki)superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑿𝑖𝑗Dec𝑆𝑈subscript𝑀𝑖𝑠subscript𝑘𝑖\sum_{j=1}^{m}{\boldsymbol{X}}_{ij}=\emph{Dec}\left(SUM_{i},sk_{i}\right).

With encryption, our PPSGCN framework achieves reliable privacy preservation in the star-topology client-server system. To the best of our knowledge, our framework is the first to address privacy concerns in distributed training of graph neural networks.

4. Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we prove the convergence of the PPSGCN algorithm and analyze its training overhead in comparison to baselines.

4.1. Convergence

We have the following theorem to guarantee for the convergence of our proposed PPSGCN algorithm.

Theorem 1.

Let ‖∇ℒ​(𝐖T)¯‖2=1T​∑t=0T−1‖∇ℒ​(𝐖t)‖2subscriptnorm¯∇ℒsubscript𝐖𝑇21𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscriptnorm∇ℒsubscript𝐖𝑡2\|\overline{\nabla\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{T}\right)}\|_{2}=\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\|\nabla\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)\|_{2}. With a proper learning rate η≤1ρ𝜂1𝜌\eta\leq\frac{1}{\rho}, Algorithm 1 would converge to a local optimum with probability 111, i.e,

‖∇ℒ​(𝑾T)¯‖2≤ℒ​(𝑾0)−ℒ​(𝑾T)T​η​(1−12​ρ​η).subscriptnorm¯∇ℒsubscript𝑾𝑇2ℒsubscript𝑾0ℒsubscript𝑾𝑇𝑇𝜂112𝜌𝜂\|\overline{\nabla\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{T}\right)}\|_{2}\leq\sqrt{\frac{\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{0}\right)-\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{T}\right)}{T\eta\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\rho\eta\right)}}.
Proof.

Since the loss function ℒℒ\mathcal{L} defined in Equation 4 has ρ𝜌\rho-continuous gradient, the follow inequality holds for the parameters 𝑾t+1subscript𝑾𝑡1{\boldsymbol{W}}_{t+1} and 𝑾tsubscript𝑾𝑡{\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}, i.e,

ℒ​(𝑾t+1)≤ℒ​(𝑾t)+∇ℒ​(𝑾t)T​(𝑾t+1−𝑾t)+ρ2​‖𝑾t+1−𝑾t‖22.ℒsubscript𝑾𝑡1ℒsubscript𝑾𝑡∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑡𝑇subscript𝑾𝑡1subscript𝑾𝑡𝜌2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑾𝑡1subscript𝑾𝑡22\displaystyle\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t+1}\right)\leq\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)+\nabla\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)^{T}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t+1}-{\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)+\frac{\rho}{2}\|{\boldsymbol{W}}_{t+1}-{\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\|_{2}^{2}.

Substitute 𝑾t+1=𝑾t−η​∇ℒs​(𝑾t)subscript𝑾𝑡1subscript𝑾𝑡𝜂∇subscriptℒ𝑠subscript𝑾𝑡{\boldsymbol{W}}_{t+1}={\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}-\eta\nabla{\mathcal{L}}_{s}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right) into the right side of the inequality above and take mathematical expectation on both sides, then we arrive at

ℒ​(𝑾t+1)ℒsubscript𝑾𝑡1\displaystyle\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t+1}\right) ≤ℒ​(𝑾t)−η​∇ℒ​(𝑾t)T​𝔼​[∇ℒS​(𝑾t)]absentℒsubscript𝑾𝑡𝜂∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑾𝑡𝑇𝔼delimited-[]∇subscriptℒ𝑆subscript𝑾𝑡\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)-\eta\nabla\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)^{T}\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla{\mathcal{L}_{S}}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)\right]
+ρ​η22​‖𝔼​[∇ℒS​(𝑾t)]‖22.𝜌superscript𝜂22superscriptsubscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]∇subscriptℒ𝑆subscript𝑾𝑡22\displaystyle\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad+\frac{\rho\eta^{2}}{2}\|\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla{\mathcal{L}_{S}}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)\right]\|_{2}^{2}.

Since 𝔼​[∇ℒS​(𝑾t)]=∇ℒ​(𝑾t)+(𝔼​[∇ℒS​(𝑾t)]−∇ℒ​(𝑾t))𝔼delimited-[]∇subscriptℒ𝑆subscript𝑾𝑡∇ℒsubscript𝑾𝑡𝔼delimited-[]∇subscriptℒ𝑆subscript𝑾𝑡∇ℒsubscript𝑾𝑡\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla{\mathcal{L}_{S}}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)\right]=\nabla\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)+\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla{\mathcal{L}_{S}}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)\right]-\nabla\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)\right), we have

(11) ℒ​(𝑾t+1)≤ℒ​(𝑾t)ℒsubscript𝑾𝑡1ℒsubscript𝑾𝑡\displaystyle\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t+1}\right)\leq\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right) −(η−ρ​η22)​‖∇ℒ​(𝑾t)‖22𝜂𝜌superscript𝜂22superscriptsubscriptnorm∇ℒsubscript𝑾𝑡22\displaystyle-\left(\eta-\frac{\rho\eta^{2}}{2}\right)\|\nabla\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)\|_{2}^{2}
+(η−ρ​η2)​δ​ℒt​‖∇ℒ​(𝑾t)‖2+ρ​η22​δ​ℒt2𝜂𝜌superscript𝜂2𝛿subscriptℒ𝑡subscriptnorm∇ℒsubscript𝑾𝑡2𝜌superscript𝜂22𝛿superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑡2\displaystyle+\left(\eta-\rho\eta^{2}\right)\delta\mathcal{L}_{t}\|\nabla\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)\|_{2}+\frac{\rho\eta^{2}}{2}\delta\mathcal{L}_{t}^{2}

for η≤1ρ𝜂1𝜌\eta\leq\frac{1}{\rho}, where δ​ℒt=‖∇ℒ​(𝑾t)−𝔼​[∇ℒS​(𝑾t)]‖2𝛿subscriptℒ𝑡subscriptnorm∇ℒsubscript𝑾𝑡𝔼delimited-[]∇subscriptℒ𝑆subscript𝑾𝑡2\delta\mathcal{L}_{t}=\|\nabla\mathcal{L}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)-\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla\mathcal{L}_{S}\left({\boldsymbol{W}}_{t}\right)\right]\|_{2}.

According to the strong law of large numbers, for any v∈𝒱Si𝑣subscript𝒱subscript𝑆𝑖v\in\mathcal{V}_{S_{i}}, we have 𝑯Sil​[v,:]→𝑯il​[v,:]→superscriptsubscript𝑯subscript𝑆𝑖𝑙𝑣:superscriptsubscript𝑯𝑖𝑙𝑣:{\boldsymbol{H}}_{S_{i}}^{l}\left[v,:\right]\rightarrow{\boldsymbol{H}}_{i}^{l}\left[v,:\right] as the number of sampled nodes from each client go to infinity. In this sense, the inequality Equation 11 turns to

Sum up all terms from t=0𝑡0t=0 to T−1𝑇1T-1 on both sides, we arrive at

holds for η≤1ρ𝜂1𝜌\eta\leq\frac{1}{\rho}. ∎

4.2. Training Overhead

4.2.1. Communication Overhead

Communication steps are shown in Algorithm 1. In the forward propagation, each client Cjsubscript𝐶𝑗C_{j} sends m−1𝑚1m-1 local terms 𝑳i​j​𝑶jl−1subscript𝑳𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑶𝑗𝑙1{\boldsymbol{L}}_{ij}{\boldsymbol{O}}_{j}^{l-1} for i=1,⋯,m𝑖1⋯𝑚i=1,\cdots,m to the central server. Then the central server adds them up as S​U​Mi=∑j≠i𝑳i​j​𝑶jl−1𝑆𝑈subscript𝑀𝑖subscript𝑗𝑖subscript𝑳𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑶𝑗𝑙1SUM_{i}=\sum_{j\neq i}{\boldsymbol{L}}_{ij}{\boldsymbol{O}}_{j}^{l-1} for i=1,⋯,m𝑖1⋯𝑚i=1,\cdots,m. Finally, central server sends S​U​Mi𝑆𝑈subscript𝑀𝑖SUM_{i} to client Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i}, 𝒁Silsuperscriptsubscript𝒁subscript𝑆𝑖𝑙{\boldsymbol{Z}}_{S_{i}}^{l} is consequently calculated within Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i}. The communication volume required for forward propagation in Equation 9 is L​m​nS​d𝐿𝑚subscript𝑛𝑆𝑑Lmn_{S}d per iteration. In the backward propagation, calculation of ∇𝒁SiLℒsubscript∇subscriptsuperscript𝒁𝐿subscript𝑆𝑖ℒ\nabla_{{\boldsymbol{Z}}^{L}_{S_{i}}}{\mathcal{L}} requires no communication because ∇𝒁SjLL​o​s​si=0,i≠jformulae-sequencesubscript∇subscriptsuperscript𝒁𝐿subscript𝑆𝑗𝐿𝑜𝑠subscript𝑠𝑖0𝑖𝑗\nabla_{{\boldsymbol{Z}}^{L}_{S_{j}}}Loss_{i}=0,\ i\neq j. For Equation 6, we follow the same communication steps as forward propagation with 𝑳i​j​𝑷jlsubscript𝑳𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑷𝑗𝑙{\boldsymbol{L}}_{ij}{\boldsymbol{P}}_{j}^{l} as local terms. L​m​nS​d𝐿𝑚subscript𝑛𝑆𝑑Lmn_{S}d communication volume is required by Equation 6 to aggregate gradient information. For Equation 7, we save the result ∇𝒁Sil−1ℒSsubscript∇subscriptsuperscript𝒁𝑙1subscript𝑆𝑖subscriptℒ𝑆\nabla_{{\boldsymbol{Z}}^{l-1}_{S_{i}}}\mathcal{L}_{S} locally and each client Cisubscript𝐶𝑖C_{i} sends only one local gradient (𝒁Sil−1)T​∇𝒁Sil−1ℒSsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒁𝑙1subscript𝑆𝑖𝑇subscript∇subscriptsuperscript𝒁𝑙1subscript𝑆𝑖subscriptℒ𝑆\left({\boldsymbol{Z}}^{l-1}_{S_{i}}\right)^{T}\nabla_{{\boldsymbol{Z}}^{l-1}_{S_{i}}}\mathcal{L}_{S} to the central server. Then the central server sums them up and derives global gradient as S​U​M=∑i=1m(𝒁Sil−1)T​∇𝒁Sil−1ℒS𝑆𝑈𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒁𝑙1subscript𝑆𝑖𝑇subscript∇subscriptsuperscript𝒁𝑙1subscript𝑆𝑖subscriptℒ𝑆SUM=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\left({\boldsymbol{Z}}^{l-1}_{S_{i}}\right)^{T}\nabla_{{\boldsymbol{Z}}^{l-1}_{S_{i}}}\mathcal{L}_{S}. Finally, central server scatters S​U​M𝑆𝑈𝑀SUM to all clients to update local models with the same global gradient. The communication volume for Equation 7 is 2​L​m​d22𝐿𝑚superscript𝑑22Lmd^{2}. Therefore, the total communication cost in one iteration of PPSGCN is 2​L​m​d​(nS+d)2𝐿𝑚𝑑subscript𝑛𝑆𝑑2Lmd\left(n_{S}+d\right).

4.2.2. Memory Overhead

In each training epoch, a partition of the feature matrix is sampled and stored in memory. Therefore, our training data size is nS​dsubscript𝑛𝑆𝑑n_{S}d, and nS​L​dsubscript𝑛𝑆𝐿𝑑n_{S}Ld in total for L𝐿L layers. Besides, the model parameters are held in each client and call for m​L​d2𝑚𝐿superscript𝑑2mLd^{2} of memory in total. Therefore, the overall memory overhead of PPSGCN is nS​L​d+m​L​d2subscript𝑛𝑆𝐿𝑑𝑚𝐿superscript𝑑2n_{S}Ld+mLd^{2}.

4.2.3. Model Comparision

We compare PPSGCN with existing distributed GCN algorithms in Table 1. As Table 1 shows, typically we have BDS-GCN ≤\leq PPSGCN, CES-GCN ≤\leq CAGNET for communication overhead and PPSGCN ≤\leq BDS-GCN ≤\leq CES-GCN ≤\leq CAGNET for memory overhead. Specifically, L<tbL𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑏𝐿L<t_{b}^{L} holds in most cases, so PPSGCN has lower communication overhead than CES-GCN when clients number m𝑚m is small. Therefore, we achieve the lowest memory and communication overhead without introducing redundant memory of feature data in the training process. For BDS-GCN (Wan et al., 2020), the reason for their lower communication overhead is that they reduce communication overhead by introducing redundant memory of boundary node features in different devices. In fact, BDS-GCN could be seen as a specific option in our sampling step where pv=1subscript𝑝𝑣1p_{v}=1 when v∈ℬ𝑣ℬv\in{\mathcal{B}} and pv=1nSsubscript𝑝𝑣1subscript𝑛𝑆p_{v}=\frac{1}{n_{S}} otherwise. Moreover, through results shown in Table 1, sampling technique largely reduces both training and memory overhead and makes GCN training more scalable in distributed setting. Furthermore, subgraph sampling methods (PPSGCN, BDS-GCN) better mitigate neighbour explosion problems and improve training efficiency with lower communication and memory overhead, compared to node sampling. Besides, our proposed PPSGCN is the only method that achieves the goal of preserving data privacy.

5. Experiments

In this section, we empirically evaluate the proposed PPSGCN with three prevalent node classification tasks and compare it with various centralized and distributed GCN training methods on both model performance and training overhead. We also conduct ablation study and analyze the effect of batch size and normalization.

5.1. Experimental Set-up

5.1.1. Dataset

We adopt three prevalent datasets in previous works (Sen et al., 2008; Hamilton et al., 2017a; Hu et al., 2020) to evalueate PPSGCN: Pubmed 111https://linqs.soe.ucsc.edu/data, Reddit 222http://snap.stanford.edu/graphsage/ and Ogbn-products 333https://github.com/snap-stanford/ogb. PubMed is a citation network with nodes as scientific papers and edges as citations; Reddit is a large social network consisting of reddit posts in different communities, with nodes as posts and two posts share an edge when they are commented by one Reddit user; Ogbn-products is an Amazon product co-purchasing network where nodes represent products and edges indicate that the products are purchased together. We present details and statistics of these datasets in Table 2.

5.1.2. Baseline

We compare PPSGCN with existing methods in both centralized and distributed settings. For centralized methods,

  • •

    GCN (Kipf and Welling, 2016), which introduces convolutional layers to graph neural networks.

  • •

    GAT (Veličković et al., 2017), which introduces the attention mechanism to graph neural networks.

  • •

    LinkDist (Luo et al., 2021), which substitutes message-passing neighbour aggregation with MLP in graph neural networks.

  • •

    GraphSAINT (Zeng et al., 2019), which proposes an inductive GCN training method with subgraph sampling and normalization.

For distributed methods, we have

  • •

    CAGNET (Tripathy et al., 2020), which presents several distributed GCN training techniques where computation is conducted on small client groups in parallel.

  • •

    a communication-efficient sampling method (Jiang and Rumi, 2021), denoted as CES-GCN, which proposes a skewed sampling technique for distributed GCN training.

  • •

    BDS-GCN (Wan et al., 2020), which proposes a boundary node sampling technique for distributed GCN training.

5.1.3. Implementation

We implement PPSGCN and existing baselines with the CPU version of Pytorch. To simulate a distributed learning setting, we use the communication primitives of the ”Gloo” backend in torch.distributed. We randomly partition datasets into different subsets as in Equation 1 and assign each subset to a training process. We use the Adam optimizer (Kingma and Ba, 2014) to learn model parameters. We make our code available at Dropbox. 444https://www.dropbox.com/sh/hetdibd8x3ktjjc/AAAxpr8fsEMR12_pBMk4S5lxa?dl=0

5.2. Experiment Results

We present the performance of PPSGCN and baselines on three datasets in Table 3. For all methods, we fix the hidden feature dimension at 128, and the dropout probability at 0.2. We independently search for the optimal learning rate among 0.1, 0.01 and 0.001 in each case. We train a 2-layer PPSGCN model on PubMed, and 3-layer model for Reddit and Ogbn-products. For centralized baselines, we run 2-layer GCN and GAT models in our transductive setting for 200 epochs on the Pubmed dataset. For distributed baselines, we fix the number of clients at 8 to ensure the fairness.

Table 3 demonstrates that our proposed PPSGCN generally outperforms existing baslines, which bears out the effectiveness of our method in the distributed setting. Especially, we achieve state-of-the-art performance on PubMed dataset with transductive setting, and outstrip most centralized methods on the largest dataset Ogbn-products. Moreover, experiment results verify the effectiveness of sampling methods (GraphSAINT, BDS-GCN and PPSGCN) on both training scalability and performance, especially on large graphs.

5.3. Training Overhead Study

PPSGCN aims to tackle the issues of heavy training overhead in existing methods. We analyze whether our proposed PPSGCN successfully reduces communication and memory overhead in its training process.

5.3.1. Communication Overhead

We firstly study PPSGCN’s communication overhead and compare it with existing methods. Model training time in these methods could be partitioned into local computation and communication over processes. For communication overhead, we record the time of communication function calls such as broadcast and reduce. We compare our proposed method with CAGNET (Tripathy et al., 2020) and present the results in Table 4. It is demonstrated that PPSGCN involves consistently lower communication overhead in both 4-client and 8-client settings. Especially in large datasets, e.g. Ogbn-products, PPSGCN reduces communication overhead for over 80% and local computation time for over 90% compared with CAGNET. Moreover, the communication overhead in the 8-client setting increases a little with regard to 4-client, while local communication time exhibits a significant decrease, which leads to lower training time cost even with more clients.

5.3.2. Memory Overhead

Besides, we also examine whether PPSGCN reduces memory overhead in the training process. The memory cost primarily consists of two parts, node features in pytorch computational graphs and model parameters, which are distributed in different clients. We record memory costs in one epoch for each client in Table 4. As Table 4 shows, PPSGCN largely reduces memory overhead for over 80% decrease in each case.

5.4. Ablation Study

We observe that sampling and normalization greatly impact the performance of PPSGCN. Thus, we design ablation experiments to remove them separately and run experiments with ablated versions. Results in Table 5 demonstrate that PPSGCN has the best performance in most cases. And PPSGCN* has a bit lower performance but still better than PPSGCN-full. Since the normalization coefficient satisfies 1α>11𝛼1\frac{1}{\alpha}>1, PPSGCN has a larger variance on performance than PPSGCN*. As a result, both sampling and normalization steps are crucial to PPSGCN’s desirable performance.

5.5. Discussion

5.5.1. Convergence Study

Besides low training overhead, our proposed PPSGCN also has high convergence rate, and both factors are significant to the overall training efficiency. To prove the fast convergence of PPSGCN, we record the micro f1-score and training time in each epoch. In Figure 2, we illustrate the convergence curves of PPSGCN and its full-batch counterpart PPSGCN-full, namely the change in micro f1-score with training time. It is demonstrated that PPSGCN requires significantly less time to converge while achieving similar or even better performance. This indicates that our subgraph sampling method greatly contributes to the algorithm’s rapid convergence.

5.5.2. Batch Size Study

In the experiments, we observed that the batch size in PPSGCN has significant effect on model efficiency. We further conduct experiments with different batch size and present the results in Figure 3. For each epoch, we fix the number of training nodes at 100,000. When step length equals 2, batch size equals 50,000 and model parameters are updated twice per epoch. After training for 10 epochs, we obtain the average communication cost and local computation time. Figure 3 illustrates that as we augment the step length, communication time keeps increasing and local computation time decreases with a decaying rate. In particular, total training time reaches minimum when step length equals 12. This indicates that step length (and consequently batch size) governs the trade-off between local computation and communication overhead, where the optimal value varies in different experiment settings.

6. Conclusion

We presented PPSGCN, a novel distributed GCN training method. Specifically, we sample a local node subset in each client to form a global subgraph. After local computation with features or gradients of the sampled nodes, all clients combine local results by securely communicating with the central server with homomorphic encryption. We analyzed that training on subgraphs largely reduces the communication and memory overhead, while encrypted communication successfully preserves data privacy. We also proved the convergence of our PPSGCN algorithm. Finally, we conducted extensive experiments to compare PPSGCN with various baselines, which demonstrates that our proposed PPSGCN method largely reduces training overhead while maintaining desirable performance.

A future direction is to further examine the relationship between distributed GNN models and federated graph learning. It’s possible to propose a paradigm that jointly incorporates them in a profound perspective to better solve real-world problems.
